channel.title: Daily HealthBeat Tip PodCast
channel.description: Welcome to HHS HealthBeat. Launched on July 11, 2005, this service provides health promotion and disease prevention tips 5 days a week in audio and text formats.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Public Health Podcasts
channel.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov

itunes:owner.itunes:name: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)

item.title: On the vaccine schedule
item.description: Parents are doing well in getting their kids vaccinated on schedule. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says rates are at record highs, or near them. But some kids are still coming down with diseases they would not have gotten if they were vaccinated.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: Parents are doing well in getting their kids vaccinated on schedule. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says rates are at record highs, or near them. But some kids are still coming down with diseases they would not have gotten if they were vaccinated.

item.title: Hands, feet and mouths
item.description: Kids can’t get hoof and mouth disease – that’s for livestock – but they can get something that sounds very similar.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: Kids can’t get hoof and mouth disease – that’s for livestock – but they can get something that sounds very similar.

item.title: Deep vein travelers
item.description: It’s possible, but rare, for some people who have to sit for long periods, like on a long airplane flight, to get deep vein thrombosis.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: It’s possible, but rare, for some people who have to sit for long periods, like on a long airplane flight, to get deep vein thrombosis.

item.title: Tans, burns and cancer
item.description: Is a tan really worth risking skin cancer for? Researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention looked at national survey data, and reported that half of adults under 30 had at least one sunburn in a year. Burns raise the risk of skin cancer.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: Is a tan really worth risking skin cancer for? Researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention looked at national survey data, and reported that half of adults under 30 had at least one sunburn in a year. Burns raise the risk of skin cancer.

item.title: Swallowed batteries
item.description: Button batteries are good for electronics but very bad for kids. Researchers report more than 5,500 battery-related emergency department visits in 2009 by people under age 18.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: Button batteries are good for electronics but very bad for kids. Researchers report more than 5,500 battery-related emergency department visits in 2009 by people under age 18.

item.title: Medical decision-making after a traumatic brain injury
item.description: People who’ve had traumatic brain injury might not be thinking straight but still may have to make crucial medical decisions.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: People who’ve had traumatic brain injury might not be thinking straight but still may have to make crucial medical decisions.

item.title: Maintaining a healthy heart
item.description: Good health habits in young adulthood can pay off big later. Following people for 20 years, beginning at young adulthood, researchers examined healthy lifestyle factors.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: Good health habits in young adulthood can pay off big later. Following people for 20 years, beginning at young adulthood, researchers examined healthy lifestyle factors.

item.title: Fighting fat genes
item.description: A researcher at the Harvard School of Public Health says even people with fat genes can control their weight.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: A researcher at the Harvard School of Public Health says even people with fat genes can control their weight.

item.title: Managing your blood pressure
item.description: Your diet, how much you exercise, how much salt you eat, and your age can affect your blood pressure. And if you have high blood pressure, you’re at risk for heart attack, stroke, and kidney failure. The older you get, the more your risks can go up.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: Your diet, how much you exercise, how much salt you eat, and your age can affect your blood pressure. And if you have high blood pressure, you’re at risk for heart attack, stroke, and kidney failure. The older you get, the more your risks can go up.

item.title: Life after smoking
item.description: It’s not easy, but it could be the most important decision you ever make. Quitting smoking, or never starting, is so vital to your health. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has launched a new campaign, Tips from Former Smokers, to show just how harsh tobacco can be, first and second hand.
item.author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov (Ira Dreyfuss)
item.itunes:author: Ira.Dreyfuss@hhs.gov
item.itunes:summary: It’s not easy, but it could be the most important decision you ever make. Quitting smoking, or never starting, is so vital to your health. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has launched a new campaign, Tips from Former Smokers, to show just how harsh tobacco can be, first and second hand.
